title: 8. An Overview of the Ovarian Cycle

vectorData.altText: H12   An Overview of the Ovarian Cycle

Starting at puberty, each month, a small number of primordial follicles      grows larger, but usually only one becomes the dominant follicle, and its egg is released from the ovary at ovulation. This phase of the ovarian cycle is called the follicular phase. The follicular phase lasts, on average, 14 days, although it varies from 7 to 21 days between individuals. 
This is followed by the luteal phase, during which time, as the ovum travels down the fallopian tube toward the uterus, the empty follicle becomes a temporary endocrine structure, the                corpus luteum           . Hormones secreted by the corpus luteum prepare the uterine mucosa for implantation, should pregnancy occur. If pregnancy does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates after 14 days, forming the corpus albicans            , and another group of primordial follicles begin to enlarge with the onset of the next follicular phase.
Thus, the ovarian cycle lasts for a total of 21-35 days, depending on the duration of the follicular phase in a given individual.

Remember, a primordial follicle consists of a 1° oocyte (halted in the prophase of the first meiotic division), surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells. A basement membrane separates it from the surrounding, vascularized, ovarian stroma.
“yellow body”; so-named because it appears yellow due to the high content of  lipids, the precursors of steroid hormones.
“white body”; so-named because it is fibrous CT scar tissue, and its high collagen content makes it appear white.
This histological image of the ovary shows a corpus albicans (CA). Notice how the abundance of collagen makes the corpus albicans appear white!
This histological image of the ovary shows a corpus luteum (CL). The corpus luteum contains a high concentration of lipids, which makes it appear yellow.
